an3.93:1.1: “Mendicants, wanderers of other religions advocate three kinds of seclusion.
an3.93:1.3: Seclusion in robes, almsfood, and lodgings.
an3.93:2.1: Wanderers of other religions advocate this kind of seclusion in robes. They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
an3.93:2.2: This is what wanderers of other religions advocate for seclusion in robes.
an3.93:3.1: Wanderers of other religions advocate this kind of seclusion in almsfood.
an3.93:3.2: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
an3.93:3.3: This is what the wanderers of other religions advocate for seclusion in almsfood.
an3.93:4.1: Wanderers of other religions advocate this kind of seclusion in lodgings. They stay in a wilderness, at the root of a tree, in a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw, or a threshing-hut.
an3.93:4.2: This is what wanderers of other religions advocate for seclusion in lodgings.
an3.93:4.3: These are the three kinds of seclusion that wanderers of other religions advocate.
an3.93:5.1: In this teaching and training, there are three kinds of seclusion for a mendicant.
an3.93:5.3: Firstly, a mendicant is ethical, giving up unethical conduct, being secluded from it.
an3.93:5.4: They have right view, giving up wrong view, being secluded from it.
an3.93:5.5: They’ve ended defilements, giving up defilements, being secluded from them.
an3.93:5.6: When a mendicant has these three kinds of seclusion,
an3.93:5.9: they’re called a mendicant who has reached the peak and the pith, being pure and grounded in the essential.
an3.93:6.1: When a farmer’s rice field is ripe,
an3.93:6.2: they’d have the rice cut swiftly,
an3.93:6.7: the straw and chaff removed swiftly,
an3.93:6.12: and have the husks removed swiftly.
an3.93:6.13: In this way that farmer’s crop would reach the peak and the pith, being pure and established in the pith.
an3.93:7.1: In the same way, when a mendicant is ethical, giving up unethical conduct, being secluded from it;
an3.93:7.2: when they have right view, giving up wrong view, being secluded from it;
an3.93:7.3: when they’ve ended defilements, giving up defilements, being secluded from them:
an3.93:7.4: they’re called a mendicant who has reached the peak and the pith, being pure and grounded in the essential.”
